Review_Text: Over the years, I've tried maybe 6 Blu phones. All of them looked amazing, but we laggy to the point it drove me nuts and if take them back. I just got the Vivo XL2 and I'm absolutely happy with this phone. It's freaking stylish as usual, but it has tons of bells and whistles like a more expensive phone, and so far it works amazingly  well. I can't believe how nice this phone is for the price. Unreal. And ignore the 64 gig SD card limitation. It took my 128 gig no problem at all. LOVE MY NEW PHONE!!!  If Blu keeps this up, I'll keep buying Blu.I've had it for a week now and I still love it. It only got better. I failed to mention that this has quick charge, and comes with a case and arrives with a screen protector on the phone, with no bubbles or junk under the film. It also comes with an extra screen protector. I can't say how much I love this phone for the price paid. So happy with it.

People love to get a new phone and,  while riding that new tech high, get on Amazon and shout "BEST PHONE EVER"  when obviously it's not.  Here is my open honest list view of the Pros and Cons of this phone.Pros:Price: Even at the suggested retail of 149 usd, this phone out performs the price tagBuild quality: Built like a 700 usd flagship device. Manages to look both beautiful & professionalCall quality :  Perfect, which means it does what a phone is supposed to doScreen: at 720p its NOT as nice as an iPhone or Pixel, but it does look amazing on the 5.5 inch screenAntenna: Most forgotten feature of reviews... This phone has service in the basement of the hospital I work at, on both on Tmobile AND AT&T.  Having duel Sims,  I decided to put in both my personal and work sim cards in the phone. The Sony Xperia M5 Ultra I had before this got zero service for most parts of the basement.  This Vivo XL2 has at least 2 bars of 4g lte service through out the entire basement. Same sim cards, same Radio bands supported, and yet only this phone gets signal.Sound: loud and crisp, even with a back firing speaker.  I'd prefer a front facing speaker,  but oh well.Camera, both front and back:  Great cameras for 149 usd.... AVERAGE Camera for 700 usd.  So comparing the pictures to your iPhone or Galaxy s6 or Pixel pictures your gonna be disappointed most of the time. However, snap a pic in good lighting, share it to Facebook or Instagram, and you would be surprised how nice they look.Battery:  true 5 and 1/2 hours of screen-on time which is absolutely amazing.  However, though they claim its quick charging, it's really not.  2 hours to fully charge from 25% isn't standard quick charge, it's actually "not slow" charging at best.. LoLAnd finally IR blaster.  Not many phones have it anymore, but it's nice to be able to mess with the TVs at the hospital.  It's entertaining changing  the channel from Fox News to MSNBC, or vice versa, just to watch the brainwashed receptionists mind explode when someone actually disagrees with their world view.CONS:Skin/software:  Though its running Android 6.01 you'd be hard pressed to notice. The skin Blu decided to use makes it look and feel like a bunch of 16 year old kids tweaked it to something they thought looked "cool".  Easy fix,  use Nova or Google Now launcher and all is forgiven.Can't use duel sim and a MicroSD card at the same time.  Though the memory and ram upgrade (32gbs and 3gbs respectively) are more than enough for me, adding a 64 gb card will mean only using one sim card. As one slot is for a card or a sim.... It's not just this phone, but this is the one Im reviewing.No fingerprint scanner.  Can't use a lot of the new instant pay service without one.  Though at the 119 usd I paid for it, I can't complain to much.That's it with the cons. It's basically a phone on par with most flagship devices at a 1/4 of the price.I always buy unlocked carrier free versions of the phones I use as my daily driver.  The Vivo XL2 is without a doubt the best value I have ever gotten in a cell phone.  Is it the best phone ever??  Of course not.  Even Blu themselves sell better all around devices.  HOWEVER,  the XL2 may indeed be the best 149 dollar smart phone available as of March 2017.

Review_Title: Update - don't waste your money!  A pretty solid four stars.  Could have been better.
Review_Text: Update seven months in:  I've had to go from four stars to just one.  The phone worked well for about six months, though the shiny slippery back is very annoying.  But for the last month the phone has been almost unusable, and today it's become basically a brick. People who call me say they get busy signals. The phone itself freaks out. It will be normal, and then suddenly the app I'm using closes and the screen quickly flips through all the pages and then freezes on the add widget page. This happens when I'm just sitting there reading a Kindle book, typing a reply to a text, or browsing the web.  The phone will also suddenly refuse to accept input on the touch screen, or will shut down the keyboard when I'm typing.  I'll get a text, try to answer it, and the phone will shut down.  It's like it's gone insane or something.  I've tried everything, factory reset, all the updates, and even tried to get help from BLU.  All of my attempts to contact them were ignored.  Now I have to go out and try yet again to buy another phone!  I've had it with BLU and no longer recommend it.  I expect to get more than six months out of a phone!!!In the box :  phone, charger, wall adapter, headphones, screen protector, and silicone case.  Phone also had a screen protector already installed. This is my third BLU phone.  I'm disappointed that this one has a sealed battery, and if you do need two SIM cards, you can't use a  SD card.  There are only two slots, instead of three.  The fancy back that they make sound so awesome is anything but; it's not even really blue or shiny except in the brightest sunlight, and the surface is so slippery that the phone is hard to hold on to, and takes every opportunity to slide off the arm of the chair, the desktop, the nightstand, the dashboard, or anywhere else you might want to set it down.  It also has a few more quirks than my other BLUs  and was a little cranky over getting my favorite apps customized.  As much as the phone is an obvious attempt at an iphone clone, it doesn't seem to have as good an antenna as the iphone.  Meetings in an interior room in a large building mean I have no signal but I can hear coworkers phones getting texts.  That's not a huge deal for me as those meetings are only once a month and otherwise the signal is pretty reliable, and I didn't pay anywhere near $600 for the name brand.On the plus side, it does have plenty of onboard memory and readily connected with my net10 SIM card.  Apps work quickly, music sounds pretty good, and calls are clear.So overall a decent deal.  Just make sure you order a nice case when you order the phone, otherwise you'll be dropping the phone all the time, and the case that comes with it is an ugly whitish color that is just repulsive.A cautionary tale:  My first BLU phone was the  Life XL and I was very happy with it, all the utility of a $600 samsung or apple product at a fraction of the price.  Easy to set up and worked very well with my net10 account.  I"d still be using it if I hadn't dropped it on cement and made the display go all wonky.  The phone still worked just fine, but the screen was too blurry to live with.  So I ordered an identical Life XL.  Unfortunately that one came loaded with spyware. I filed a complaint with the seller, tojostore, but they refused to respond until I left bad feedback.  Then they quickly refunded my money without even asking for the phone back, so they know they were guilty.  Lesson learned, always buy just from Amazon, and immediately run a malware checker before putting any contacts or other personal information on the phone!

Review_Title: Absolutely amazing for this price range

The screen protector is the only thing holding it together.Included in the box is a 5v 2.0a charger, micoUSB cable, USB-OTG cable, earbuds with microphone, rubber phone case, screen protector, and one of those professional paper clips for opening the sim/SD card tray. As other commentators noted, you can either have 2 sim cards or 1 sim card and 1 sd card.  You cannot have all three.The phone case does not fit correctly. The case partially covers the microphone hole.There were a few Amazon apps pre-installed, but they had obviously been done so outside of the google play store as they would not update without asking the user to modify their app installation permissions.  Luckily, I was able to fully uninstall them.  After disabling what I didn't want and installing some basic google apps, it says I have used 11 GB of 32 GB.  Luckily this phone has not partitioned the main storage into multiple segments to simulate an sd card like the BLU studio energy.The display is stunning.  Good contrast between colors, very bright, and the curved edges are neat.Overall, I think this thing is perfect for $150.  But if you drop the screen, there is no replacement.

Review_Title: Best phone I've owned, definitely worth the money
Review_Text: Let me start by saying that this is the best phone I've ever owned. I've owned about 8 phones, three of which were also BLU phones. I wouldn't say it's the best phone out there, but for the price... Wow.This phone does a lot for a phone that is only $150. It looks and feels great, it's pretty fast, and, best of all, comes packed with interesting features. It has a built in fake call app, for example, for when you need to slip out of awkward situations. Now that is something else.Back on a serious note, it's a nice size, in my opinion. Not tiny but not too big. I can hold and use it comfortably. Call quality is clear and I've yet to have any issues with connecting to WiFi or the cell network. The phone also comes with a case, a screen protector already on it (and no annoying bubbles!), And an extra screen protector, should you need it. It also comes with a charger, some sort of adapter (admittedly, I don't know what it is for, so refer to another review for that answer), and a pair of earbuds. For an audio guy such as myself, the earbuds sound quite disgusting, but for average users, they should be fine.The only issue I've had with the phone itself was when I first got it. It took some time for the phone to recognize my SIM card. That was a bit frustrating, but once solved, the issue never arose again. I will say, though, that if you need to use two SIM cards, you will be unable to use a micro SD as the Micro SD and one of the SIM slots are the same slot. For me, it's no issue as I only need one SIM, but I felt it worth mentioning. The phone has 32 GB of internal space, which is more than enough for me, so I don't even need to use my SD card.There are better phones out there, obviously. But you'll be spending at least $600 to get them. This phone is way too good for the price. Thank you again, BLU, for an amazing product.

Review_Title: I absolutely love this! I don't normally do a review so ...
Review_Text: I absolutely love this! I don't normally do a review so soon (after only two days). However, this has exceeded my expectations to the point that if anything went wrong at this point, it would still be a winner in my book. Where do I start? I'll start off with the bad. I didn't care for the launcher that they use. It's very juvenile. But I always use Microsoft launcher anyway, so it wasn't a big deal. The launcher that it comes with places all of your apps on the screen. Ew! But, as I said before, that's an easy fix! I love the fact that almost everything you need is on the phone without a million and one apps. You got your barcode scanner in your camera app. Someone should have thought of that ago. You also have the option to record phone calls through your regular call app. Never saw that before. Back to the camera. It's awesome for such a low budget phone! It's almost too good! Normally your front-facing cameras don't catch your pores so well. I'll be using touch up features for that part. Lol! I love the business card scan option. It lets you scan business cards into your contacts. The free updates to Nougat didn't go so well though! Tried everything but had to factory reset. That wasn't fun. The 3GB of temporary memory is everything! I never knew that was the reason my old phone wouldn't load content very well. I thought it was my data usage allowance giving me hell! The speaker is on the back. But, honestly, who plays media through the phone speaker anymore? It's a nice-sized phone with a pretty sleek design! The charger that comes with it charges pretty decent. However, battery life could be a little better! I live with chargers all around me. So, it's not a problem for me. Kinda comes with the territory. I haven't been able to find how to make the battery notification tell me my percentage yet. I'll keep looking. The option to "close all" at the recent task menu is everything! It keeps the phone clean and working fast without the hassle of swiping then one by one all of the time! I've said enough. This phone is worth it!

Review_Title: Good phone, disastrous update to Android 7
Review_Text: i have been very happy with this phone. UNTIL I gave in to the nagging and updated to Android 7. I had to restore the phone, which then automatically updated to Android 7. If you want to update to Android 7, back up all your data to a computer (i tried to back up to the SD card but couldn't do the PDFs or screen shots), remove the SD card, and restore the phone. Otherwise the phone works well and has a strong broadcast signal that I use as a hotspot with great success.

If you read the news alerts right away, they work perfectly fine and display like they are supposed to.There are lots of little software glitches like this on this phone. It can be very annoying at times. If you just need a phone with a few apps to get you by, I would recommend this phone. I waited a couple of weeks after purchasing my BLU Vivo XL2 to write this review, so I could use it for a while before reviewing it. I love this phone! The screen is large and my videos and photos appear crystal clear and vivid. It took very little time to get my phone up and running: after I figured out how to insert my SIM card and my SD card, I was able to load all my contacts and my apps. Installation of everything was fast and easy.My previous phone was a Samsung Galaxy 5, and after just paying it off, the external speaker died. My husband's Galaxy 5 quit before mine did, so neither of us was happy about that or willing to replace it with the newest, $700 version. After doing research and reading reviews of all the options on Amazon, I decided to give this BLU phone a chance. From my experience with it so far, I can say that the BLU Vivo XL2 is the best phone you're ever going to get for such a low price. Honestly, I see no difference between my BLU phone and the Samsung I had before, and in fact the screen on my BLU is bigger, making it feel like a nice upgrade.I use my phone for the typical purposes: taking photos, reading email, texting, surfing the net, listening to music, and downloading documents to read and edit them. I am an educator, not a business person, so that may make a difference in my cell phone needs. Anyone who believes that the only good phones are made by Apple or Samsung, and who think you get that much "more" for the additional $500 or $600 will probably find things to complain about; but coming from the Galaxy 5 to this phone, I can easily say BLU has it beat.I was not a big fan of the app layout: the BLU doesn't come with an app drawer where you can put the apps you don't use often. But you can just download Nova Launcher, set up your home screen and apps the way you like, and you're all set.My only regret about this phone is that I didn't purchase it the week before, when there was a $99 flash sale. At the $149 I paid for this excellent phone, I got a great deal. At $99, it would be a steal!A recommendation: When you buy the phone, get the insurance plan. At $25 for 2 years, it's well worth it. It covers for water damage, broken screen, battery malfunction...all the common damages. I've dropped my phone a couple of times and so far, so good. But for the extra $25, it's worth it to know my phone will be replaced if I damage it.UPDATE (February 20, 2018):After having the phone for less than a year, and returning it twice for replacement and repair, I have decided to give up on it. It's unfortunate, since the phone could be great for the price. But the constant glitching, the "ghost apps" opening and closing on their own, is driving me crazy. BLU accepted the phone for repair under warranty, but the customer service was bad: no one ever contacted me to explain what was wrong with the phone; they shipped it back without any information regarding what they did to repair it. And the phone is still glitching. I ordered a Samsung Galaxy S7 phone and once it arrives I'm parting ways with this BLU phone!

Review_Title: Yes, I fell for it, but you don't have to...
Review_Text: Price seemed right, so I guess I took a shot... I assume many of you will read this and all the other reviews, good and bad, then do the same,  hoping you will be the lucky one.  It's sort of like a $160 lottery.  My advice: pay a few extra dollars, get a Samsung or some real brand and be finished with it.  I had a Samsung for a few years, was as good as new (I'm not into upgrading phones all the time, just not that important to me)... but my carrier (T-Mob) upgraded its network and I HAD to switch.  Checked everything, and the Blu seemed to have the basic features and speed I need.  Watched the video with some pseudo-geek opening the box and blathering about all kinds of statistics. Fine, I'm sold.The phone seemed to work fine at first, had to get used to the UI, which is never fun, but after a couple of weeks I had it figured out.  Reloaded my apps and seemed to be in good shape.  Nothing startling about the performance, the "long battery life & fast charging" didn't come true true but I really didn't care; I'm usually in a car and charge overnight so that is not a big issue with me (btw you can't change the battery).So here I am, just a couple of days shy of 3 months and out of the blue (no pun intended) the phone just stopped charging.  No drops, shocks, voltage spikes, etc etc. - just pfft - and it doesn't charge.  Unplug and re-plug and it starts to charge for like 30 seconds then stops; 3 different charges, 3 different cables, yeah, its the phone.  Go to my Amazon account and there is no "return" option for this device, slightly getting that sinking feeling... contacted the manufacturer.  After the customary overseas call-center "thank you for that information" (stop saying that!) and "Yes I understand sir" conversation, the result is I have to mail the phone to them and they will repair or replace with a new phone... in *10 to 15 days*.  Now, I don't know about you, but I simply cannot go for 15 days without my phone; I use it to conduct my business; waiting for 15 days is not an option.  Of course, I tried reasoning with the "manager" - you've been there - who repeated the exact same "we can only follow our standard return procedure" answer to every futile attempt I made to speed up the process. (Please, lady, at least say it slightly differently each time, try and make it sound like you're actually listening.)So I'm going to send in my phone and hope I'm the 9 day guy and not the 15 day guy (talk about lowering expectations) and have to make the decision if I double down on this disaster... Do I go and buy a REAL phone, or buy a flip-phone or some cheap alternative to fill the gap and keep as a backup for the next time -  and there WILL be a next time - I have to send the phone back?  Probably going with the REAL phone, because eventually this phone will be out of whatever warranty is covering me for this serviceSo, undoubtedly many of you who have read this far are still going to roll the dice - like I did.  But it has always been true and always will be: you get what you pay for.Good luck!

Review_Title: 9 Months of Daily Use: The Trip Report
Review_Text: Multitasking has yet to present an issue and this phone has comfortably handled everything I've thrown at it. Even comes with some nice value-added stuff I wasn't expecting (pre-installed screen protector, TPU case, earbuds, IR blaster). Some marks against it:-Don't really care for the UI or a lot of the on-board apps; many of these are installed at the system level and can't even be disabled, either. Stock Android is fine and I sincerely don't understand why manufacturers have such a stick up their ass about actually sticking to it; BLU could definitely do much better here.-This phone will take decent photos under most circumstances, but trying to take panoramic photos on this thing is an almost Sisyphean task at times; ANYTHING that forces the camera to re-focus will totally break the photo and you'll have to start from scratch.-Nine months into use in December, this phone has started to develop a nasty habit of "ghost-pressing" the back button a bunch on its own and completely unprompted, kicking you out of apps and vibrating incessantly all the while. I've apparently been lucky with mine, as this has been an oft-reported issue at least since July. I'm not sure what causes it, but considering I've never dropped this phone or exposed it to any extreme conditions, this can't speak favorably to its build quality.-I don't know if it's the included earbuds or the headphone jack, but it is notoriously difficult to consistently get this phone to pump audio through the earbuds; audio often cuts out, pipes out of the phone speakers at an obnoxious volume, etc.This phone was a steal at the time of purchase, but now I understand why, and I don't totally feel comfortable recommending it for daily use. Look elsewhere unless you just can't find something else with comparable hardware at this price point.

Review_Title: Yes, but not for the NON-tech-savvy
Review_Text: After just three days I am very pleased with the BLU Vivo XL2. But it took a bit to get to this place: out of the box I hated the custom interface -- I agree with those who described it as "heavy". Fortunately I read the Amazon reviewers who recommended replacing it with Nova Launcher, which I did, and then customized it to my liking. Now it is a beauty.The major issue has been using an SD card. I wanted this BLU for my media: audiobooks, podcasts, epubs, video and some music. I have been using Android since 2.3. Never have I had so much trouble working with an SD card. First, there are no instructions (anywhere that I could find) for working with SD cards. This is the first phone I have had with a SIM/SD drawer. There are two slots (of different sizes) in the drawer. Thank goodness another reviewer alerted me to placing the SD card in  SIM slot #1. This may seem dumb, but I was not careful when I popped the drawer out and did not notice the orientation. So when I placed SIM and SD card in the drawer the first time I had the phone display side up. This was a big mistake: when I pushed the drawer in it stuck. Obviously the wrong side, and I had to use tweezers to pry the drawer out, which was not easy. Why was this not in the quick start guide? -- to re-insert the SIM/SD drawer, the phone MUST BE DISPLAY SIDE DOWN.Secondly, since there is no information about how to use the SD card with this model I did what I have done with the Androids I have owned in the last decade or so: I allowed the Android system to format the card to its liking. After formatting, the file explorers in the Android OS or my PC (using USB cable) did not recognize the card -- no trace of it. I do not recall all of the steps I took to fix the problem (I suspected the card was not mounted, a problem I have not had with Android), but before I did I contacted BLU customer service. Other than the lack of information about using an SD card on this machine, the dull-witted BLU CS is the other reason the Vivo XL2 gets 3/5. I explained the problem to them as I have here; their response had nothing to do with this phone. I fixed the issue on my own and now my SD card is recognized and loaded with my content.For whatever reason, BLU loves the paint on this machine (the battery cover). I expected to be wowed, but no: it looks better on the computer photos. I now wish I bought the gold rather than the midnight blue.I cannot tell that the battery charges any faster than the Galaxy S3s and S4 I have used for years, but the description claimed some sort of quick charge. The battery does not seem special.BLU includes a (relatively hard) case in the package, which is nice. I usually prefer more rubbery silicone, but this one allows the phone to slip in and out of the pocket easily Unfortunately, it does not protrude over the screen and protect it. Also, the corners slip off the phone easily. I may prefer the gummy case I had for another phone, which fits better than the one made for it (the slots do not match).During baseball season I watch each of my team's games on my phone. I have not had a chance yet on this one, nor have i watched high quality video yet. But at this point I am quite pleased with the screen. I love the 5.5 inch size.I thought I might like having the power and volume on the same side of the phone, but so far I do not because it is more difficult to pick the phone up without pressing the power button.I read some reviewers comment that BLU phones do not last. Right now I am happy with the Vivo XL2, but I want it to last for years rather than a year.I would recommend it, but I worry about folks who are not tech-savvy using this phone.

Review_Title: BLU VIVO XL 2 vs ZTE ZMAX 2
Review_Text: So this seems like the first real review from someone who actually owns the phone.Just got it in the mail yesterday. This was suppose to be the Gionee P7 Max rebranded by BLU. The back isn't as shiny as Gionee so looks like BLU did a good job recasting it with their logo. This seems a lot heavier than my previous smartphone (ZTE Zmax 2) but I needed an upgrade from my 16gb internal storage and 2gb ram. VIVO XL 2 offers 32gb internal storage and 3gb ram but it definitely doesn't feel any faster than the Zmax 2. In fact, in some cases, it feels like it lags behind Zmax 2 when I only have one or two apps opened. Which I found it to be strange.Even though their width and height are quite similar (VIVO XL 2 being slightly wider), I found the Zmax 2 and its buttons a lot easier to hold and use with one or both hands. For some reason the VIVO XL 2 seems like it's almost jabbing the side of my palm when being held. I don't find it comfortable and the buttons on it are rather slimer than the Zmax 2 and while you would think that might be a plus, taking screenshots (holding lower volume+power button) and volume control is somewhat of an unnecessary hassle.Also the back finish on Zmax 2 really helps you secure having a grip on your phone whereas it's easier for VIVO XL 2 to slip in between your fingers and fall.The login screen that asks for your pattern or password for VIVO XL 2 is awkwardly place towards the top of your screen (whereas Zmax 2 place it at the bottom of your screen) - which makes it difficult to unlock it with just one hand.One good thing about VIVO XL 2 is its 13MP / 8 MP camera. While it's nothing extraordinary, it does seem to take clearer picture than the Zmax 2. The VIVO XL 2 also comes with Android Marshmallow, whereas Zmax 2 is upgradeable to that, it's installed with Lollipop.As for the accessories, all of them are WHITE. Which is a key giveaway BLU was too lazy to source their accessories to match their phone colors (since VIVO XL 2 only comes in blue and gold). It's a USB charger so it does take longer to charge your phone back up in compare to Zmax 2. Package wise, it was a lot nicer than what I expected for a phone in this price range. The phone built is pretty much what you would expect in this price range but from afar, it doesn't look cheap (if you purchased the blue version).BOTTOM LINE: If you're looking for a 32gb internal storage and 3gb of RAM with decent camera on a budget, VIVO XL 2 might be for you. If you already have a phone with 2gb of RAM, that +1gb of RAM isn't going to give you any fairytale endings.

Review_Title: Good stats, nice phone, but RMA and customer service nightmare
Review_Text: This one looked really promising.  I'd purchased it as an upgrade for the Energy X Plus, which I absolutely loved.  However within one week of opening the box, the screen started going crazy.  I tried performing soft resets, hard resets, and factory reboots, even removing my SDCard from it.  None of this worked.  I contacted BLU's support team several times in a row and kept getting canned responses back (several days later) with instructions on performing a hard reset--which I already explained (in excruciating detail in the third time) that I had done.I was finally told that I might be eligible for an RMA.  The instructions for the RMA would require me sending the phone back to them at my expense, and that basically I would have to go without a phone for several weeks while they decided if it was a hardware issue or not--and that the replacement (or my original phone) would be sent back at my expense.  Part of my work involves doing RMAs routinely, and it's standard procedure with every vendor I deal with to send the replacement along with a waybill to send the original back, then to bill the customer for the difference if the issue appears to be customer-caused or the original unit is not received.  So this is shifting the cost of doing business off to the consumer instead of the company.  I'm glad of the price cut on these versus other companies, and I totally get there are trade-offs, but this one's just a bit steep for me.  I wouldn't mind paying a bit more if it meant having a phone that I can actually use and customer service interested in making sure that I can use what I buy from them.Look, I've had good success with Blu over the past few years, and I'm not meaning to dog them over this.  I've been a huge fan since the dual-sim capabilities let me carry both my work and personal phones in one package, which is a huge convenience.  But my experiences with this phone have really left a bad taste in my mouth after seeing what happens when the phone doesn't work, and I just don't think this is one that they'll recover from easily.

Review_Title: BUYER BEWARE - BLU Products has a VERY, VERY bad warranty policy that you should consider before buying their products.
Review_Text: BUYERS BEWARE!!!!!!Any "physical damage" to the phone - including superficial chips and scratches that do to affect product performance - WILL VOID THE WARRANTY.I purchased this phone on March 1st, 2017.  The phone worked well, and I like that it came with a free case and screen protector.  Up until, the phone fell out of my pocket and hit the ground.  The case fell off and the plastic edge of the phone suffered a minor chip.  The screen was not damaged and the phone worked perfectly fine afterward, so I decided to keep the phone and buy a better case for it.Fast forward to September 2017 - seven months after the chip occurred.  The phone starts acting weird - registering "ghost touches" - backing out of applications while I am using them.  So I emailed BLU customer support and they sent me instructions on how to do a hard reset.  I followed their instructions and performed the hard reset but the problem continued.  Next I called BLU customer support.  When I spoke to a representative, I was asked "did the phone suffer and water damage or physical damage?"  I explained what had happened, the phone dropped, the case fell off, and the phone got a small chip in its case...  The CS rep told me that if the phone was subjected to "any physical damage" that the warranty was void.  I reassured them that the screen problem had nothing to do with the chip in the case - that the phone work perfectly for seven moths after the chip.  The CS rep instructed me to send a picture of the phone and a copy of my receipt so they could take a look.I took two photos of the phone - the first was a close up showing that the damage was just in the plastic case and the second was an overall shot showing how insignificant the chip was and what good condition the phone was in (see attached photos).  Needless to say, when I called back BLU Products denied my warranty claim citing "physical damage" to the phone.So I'm out $150 because BLU's case failed to protect the phone and I wasn't smart enough to return it to Amazon the minute it got chipped. (Again the case was defective.).So, please don't make the mistake I did.  Consider that if your phone get's so much as a scratch on it, BLU Products can deny any warranty claim regardless of if the scratch or chip has anything to do with the damage.Too bad.  I really liked the phone.  But the warranty policy is terrible.
